ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: Reading could take a while; some of the readings were pretty dense

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: This course was a lot of fun. I'm often disappointed with YSPH classes for not engaging in critical thinking about the social factors affecting health, and this course gave me a little outlet for it. The workload was manageable but I felt challenged and definitely learned new things.

I really liked it - it was super small, so when no one would contribute to the discussion it could get awkward! We discussed some really great topics, and I definitely learned things I did not know before
Strengths: small class size, great contentMay be improved by more interactive activities from week to week

This seminar-style course was a fantastic introduction into health disparities with an emphasis on race and socioeconomic status. The assigned readings were seminal texts in the field combined with the most current literature on these topics. I appreciated the small group discussions, as well as the methodological approaches that Dr. Jones emphasized to many of the important disparities' questions.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Beth Jones  Dr. Jones is great. I really enjoyed working with her and hearing what she had to teach. She was very accessible and caring about her students. I would definitely recommend her to other students.
Instructor: Beth Jones  Love her. Very real, down to earth, and tells it like it is.
Instructor: Beth Jones  Very enthusiastic and passionate about course content. Always willing to give feedback to students.

Instructor: Beth Jones  Dr. Jones brings decades of personal experience as a researcher; she is open-minded and did a nice job of promoting open discussion among classmates; she provides critical feedback when appropriate; she is patient, engaging, and incredibly passionate about her work and teaching

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Instructor: Adam Ismail Eldahan  We didn't have any interactions with him.
Instructor: Adam Ismail Eldahan  Unsure of how much of a part he had in coursework as he had a class conflict. Seemed more behind the scenes.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This course was fun. It was a pretty normal workload and the readings were very interesting and challenged my knowledge. It focuses on the epidemiology of measuring health disparities which was a new lens for me and I really enjoyed it. Dr. Jones is fun to work with and very caring about her students. Overall, I would recommend it.
Interesting and really made me read about things I wouldn't have chosen to read!
I would recommend this course. Great overview of disparities in chronic disease.
